snippet: Three months into what allies once called a “shock and awe” drive to dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.
abstract: Republican Party officials, activists and donors are pushing back against narrative of former Gov Jeb Bush being inevitable Republican nominee for president in 2016; Bush's less-than-stellar early campaigning contrasts poorly with successful bid by former Pres George W Bush in 2000; he is struggling not only with party's demanding ideological blocs but also with business leaders who could favor him but are still waiting for series of promised major policy speeches.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and MAGGIE HABERMAN
byline.contributor: Michael Barbaro and Trip Gabriel contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Three months into what allies once called a “shock and awe” drive to dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.

headline.main: Jeb Bush as Inevitable Choice? Republicans Say Not So Fast
headline.print_headline: Jeb Bush as Inevitable Choice? Republicans Say Not So Fast
